measured_by: Weight-lifting task adapted from Doerrfeld and colleagues
justification: The adapted weight-lifting task was used to measure how children and adults estimate the weight of objects when they anticipate lifting with or without help, effectively assessing their intuitive cost-benefit analysis in joint actions.

measured_by: Weight estimation using a standard object
justification: Estimating weight using a standard object was used to measure participants' perception of their own and others' action capabilities, including how this perception changes with the presence of a helping partner.

topic_or_construct: Social Baseline Theory effects on perception and effort
measured_by: Weight-lifting task with varying social relationships
justification: The weight-lifting task was adapted to study how social relationships with co-actors (e.g., strangers, parents, siblings) influence the perception of weight and the anticipated effort involved in joint actions.

measured_by: Differential ratios of weight estimations before and after lifting
justification: Differential ratios of weight estimations provided before and after lifting were used to measure how accurately children and adults estimated the efficiency and effort required in various joint actions with different partners.
